# Memorandum of Understanding in the Field of Social Affairs and Development
## Between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia

The Government of the State of Kuwait, represented by the "Ministry of Social Affairs / Wizarat Al-Shu'oun Al-Ijtima'iya <orig>وزارة الشؤون الاجتماعية</orig>", and the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, represented by the "Ministry of Human Resources and Social Development / Wizarat Al-Mawarid Al-Bashariya wal-Tanmiya Al-Ijtima'iya <orig>وزارة الموارد البشرية والتنمية الاجتماعية</orig>" (hereinafter referred to as "the Two Parties"), desiring to strengthen the bonds of brotherhood and cooperation between them in the fields of social development; and stemming from the existing fraternal ties and cooperative relations that unite them, and recognizing the importance of exchanging expertise and information in this field for each party to benefit from the experience of the other party; have agreed as follows:

# Council of Ministers / Majlis Al-Wuzara <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>
## Decree No. 104 of 2025
### Approving a Memorandum of Understanding
### In the Field of Social Affairs and Social Development
### Between the Government of the State of Kuwait
### And the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qa'dah 1445 AH corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And based on the presentation of the Minister of Foreign Affairs,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers / Majlis Al-Wuzara <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>,
We have decreed the following:

### Article One
#### Objective of the Memorandum
The Two Parties shall work to enhance cooperation between them in the field of social affairs and social development to achieve their common interest, in accordance with their available capabilities and in compliance with the legislation in force in both countries.

### Article One
Approval of the Memorandum of Understanding in the field of social affairs and social development between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, signed in the city of Doha <orig>الدوحة</orig> on 4 September 2024, the texts of which are attached to this Decree.

### Article Two
#### Areas of Cooperation
The Two Parties shall cooperate to achieve aspects of cooperation in the field of social affairs, and the areas of cooperation include, but are not limited to:
1- Exchanging successful experiences in the field of productive family projects, micro-enterprises, and means of financial support and empowerment.
2- Benefiting from the expertise of both parties in the field of social care directed at the following categories: (juveniles, children of unknown parentage, and the elderly).
3- Exchanging information and expertise in the field of social security and social assistance provided to specific categories of beneficiaries.
4- Exchanging information and successful experiences in various fields of social empowerment.
5- Any other field mutually agreed upon by the Two Parties later.

### Article Two
The Ministers – each within their respective jurisdiction – shall implement this Decree, which shall come into force from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette / Al-Jarida Al-Rasmiya <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.

### Article Three
#### Means of Cooperation
The Two Parties shall implement this Memorandum through various available means, including the following:
1- Exchange of information and documents.
2- Exchange of visits by delegations, professionals, and specialists.
3- Holding seminars, workshops, conferences, and meetings.
4- Any other forms of cooperation mutually agreed upon.

Amir of Kuwait
Mishal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah <orig>مشعل الأحمد الجابر الصباح</orig>

Prime Minister
Ahmed Abdullah Al-Ahmad Al-Sabah <orig>أحمد عبد الله الأحمد الصباح</orig>

Minister of Foreign Affairs
Abdullah Ali Abdullah Al-Yahya <orig>عبدالله علي عبدالله اليحيا</orig>

<footer>
Issued at Seif Palace <orig>قصر السيف</orig> on: 19 Dhu al-Hijjah 1446 AH
Corresponding to: 15 June 2025 AD
</footer>### Article Four:
**Financial Matters**
Each Party shall bear the following, according to its available capabilities:
1- Travel and accommodation expenses for its representatives.

2- The costs arising from the implementation of its obligations under this Memorandum, unless otherwise agreed by the Parties.

### Article Five
**Confidentiality**
The Parties undertake that the information and documents exchanged between them shall only be used for the designated purposes as agreed upon by the Parties, and that such information and documents shall not be transferred to a third party without the written consent of the Party that provided them.

### Article Six
**Effects of the Memorandum**
This Memorandum shall not create any right or obligation governed by international law; nor shall its provisions prejudice the obligations, rights, and privileges of the Parties arising from any international treaty or agreement.

### Article Seven
**Settlement of Disputes**
Any dispute arising between the Parties regarding the interpretation or implementation of this Memorandum shall be settled amicably through consultations between the Parties via diplomatic channels.

### Article Eight
**General Provisions**
1- This Memorandum shall enter into force from the date of receipt of the last notification by which one Party informs the other Party in writing and through diplomatic channels of its completion of the necessary national procedures for the entry into force of the Memorandum of Understanding.
2- This Memorandum may be amended by mutual written consent of the Parties through diplomatic channels, and such amendments shall enter into force in accordance with the procedures stipulated in paragraph (1) of this Article.
3- This Memorandum shall remain in force for a period of (five years), and shall be automatically renewed for a similar period or periods, unless one Party notifies the other Party in writing, and through diplomatic channels, of its desire to terminate it, at least six months prior to its termination or expiry date.
4- The cancellation or termination of this Memorandum shall not prejudice the completion of ongoing activities that have already commenced, until their completion, unless otherwise agreed by the Parties.

# Decree No. 105 of 2025
## Approving a Memorandum of Understanding
## for Cooperation in the Field of Social Insurance
## Between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the State of Qatar

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And based on the presentation of the Minister of Foreign Affairs,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers,

We have decreed the following:

### Article One
Approval of the Memorandum of Understanding for cooperation in the field of social insurance between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the State of Qatar, signed in the city of Doha <orig>الدوحة</orig> on 3 February 2025, the texts of which are attached to this Decree.

### Article Two
Ministers – each within their respective competencies – shall implement this Decree, which shall come into effect from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette.

Amir of Kuwait
Mishal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah <orig>مشعل الأحمد الجابر الصباح</orig>

Prime Minister
Ahmed Abdullah Al-Ahmad Al-Sabah <orig>أحمد عبدالله الأحمد الصباح</orig>

Minister of Foreign Affairs
Abdullah Ali Abdullah Al-Yahya <orig>عبد الله علي عبد الله اليحيا</orig>

Issued at Seif Palace <orig>قصر السيف</orig> on: 19 Dhu al-Hijjah 1446 AH
Corresponding to: 15 June 2025 AD

## MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING
## FOR COOPERATION IN THE FIELD OF SOCIAL INSURANCE
## BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF KUWAIT AND THE GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF QATAR

The Government of the State of Kuwait, represented by the "Public Institution for Social Security <orig>المؤسسة العامة للتأمينات الاجتماعية</orig>", and the Government of the State of Qatar, represented by the "General Retirement and Social Insurance Authority <orig>الهيئة العامة للتقاعد والتأمينات الاجتماعية</orig>",
Hereinafter referred to as "the Parties",
Embodying the historical ties between the State of Kuwait and the State of Qatar, and in support of joint efforts to enhance and develop bilateral cooperation in the field of social insurance,
And recognizing the importance of exchanging experiences, studies, and information related to social insurance due to its effective role in achieving social progress,
And seeking to benefit from their experience and expertise in the field of social insurance,
Have agreed as follows:

### Article One
### Principles of Cooperation

Cooperation between the Parties under this Memorandum shall be in accordance with the following principles:
1. All activities and works carried out under this Memorandum shall be implemented on the basis of equality, reciprocity, and mutual interests.
2. Due consideration shall be given to the laws and regulations in force in both countries and the available capabilities of both the Public Institution for Social Security <orig>المؤسسة العامة للتأمينات الاجتماعية</orig> in the State of Kuwait and the General Retirement and Social Insurance Authority <orig>الهيئة العامة للتقاعد والتأمينات الاجتماعية</orig> in the State of Qatar.
3. The confidentiality of information exchanged under this Memorandum shall be maintained, whether such information is written, visual, audio, or electronic data.

### Article Two
### Exchange of Expertise

The Parties aim, under this Memorandum, to exchange their expertise in the field of social insurance in all its forms and levels, particularly in the following areas:
1. Developing legislation for pension, gratuity, and social insurance systems aimed at improving insurance performance and the sustainability of pension funds.
2. Research, studies, statistics, annual reports, and publications issued by the Public Institution for Social Security <orig>المؤسسة العامة للتأمينات الاجتماعية</orig> in the State of Kuwait and the General Retirement and Social Insurance Authority <orig>الهيئة العامة للتقاعد والتأمينات الاجتماعية</orig> in the State of Qatar, and any other publications related to their activities such as books, periodicals, procedural and guidance work manuals, and statistical and informational bulletins.
3. Plans, strategies, and studies related to the development of insurance and social security systems.
4. Fact-finding visits to learn about the systems applied by the Parties, how they are organized and managed, and the achievements made in this field.
5. Extending invitations to attend seminars, conferences, and joint meetings held in both countries to discuss issues and matters of interest to the Parties.
6. Sending and seconding experts, consultants, and specialists working between the Parties, according to work requirements and the needs of the executive and developmental programs of either Party.
7. Training and developing the professional capabilities and skills of the employees of both Parties.

Article Three
Training and Qualification of Insurance Cadres
Both parties shall share activities and works related to the training and qualification of employees organized by each of them, as follows:
1. Exchange of plans, programs, and training courses offered by each party through direct communication and official correspondence, and reviewing the experiences of the other party.
2. Participation in organizing training courses, scientific seminars, workshops, and scientific research competitions for employees in agencies, bodies, and institutions concerned with social insurance, with the aim of enhancing regional and international cooperation with counterpart agencies, addressing the shortage in specialized training programs in the Arab region, and enriching the scientific knowledge of employees and expanding their understanding of new developments in the field of insurance in its various branches, and the technologies used in this field and their applications.
3. Utilizing insurance experts as trainers and lecturers between the two parties to participate in implementing and covering activities and works related to the training and qualification of insurance cadres.
4. Promoting the use of modern remote visual communication methods to organize training and qualification activities, taking into account developments in the work environment, and enhancing the continuity of training and development for employees.
Article Four
Exchange of Technical Consultations
The two parties shall exchange technical consultations in the field of social insurance, related to legal, insurance, investment, and risk management matters, and proposals on all new developments in the field of social insurance in both countries.
Article Five
Exchange Related to Services, Information Systems, and Communications
The two parties shall exchange expertise, experiences, and consultations regarding information and communication technology systems and the digital transformation policy for work systems and services applied by the Public Institution for Social Security <orig>المؤسسة العامة للتأمينات الاجتماعية</orig> in the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the General Retirement and Social Insurance Authority <orig>الهيئة العامة للتقاعد والتأمينات الاجتماعية</orig> in the State of Qatar <orig>دولة قطر</orig>, in addition to their electronic services and archiving systems, and their management mechanism.
Article Six
Exchange Related to Collection, Disbursement, and Inspection Procedures
The two parties shall exchange expertise, experiences, and field training regarding collection and disbursement procedures, and the financial, administrative, and legal procedures related to contributions and pensions, in addition to the procedures and rules of insurance inspection in terms of its types and legal forms applied by both parties.
Article Seven
Exchange Related to Other Insurances
The two parties shall exchange expertise, experiences, and field training regarding other insurances applied by both parties, such as unemployment insurance, work injury insurance, occupational diseases, and other insurances and benefits stipulated for insured persons and pensioners, and the legislative systems related to these insurances and their funding systems, in addition to work mechanisms and coordination with other relevant authorities.
Article Eight
Confidentiality of Information
Both parties undertake to maintain the confidentiality of all information exchanged between them under this Memorandum, in whatever form it may be.
Each party undertakes not to disclose or transfer information obtained from the other party under this Memorandum to any third party, except after obtaining prior explicit written consent from the other party that provided such information. This obligation to maintain confidentiality shall remain in effect even after the termination of this Memorandum.
Article Nine
Joint Committee
The two parties shall form a joint committee consisting of (4) members from each party to carry out planning and follow-up work for the implementation of the provisions of this Memorandum, and its tasks shall be as follows:
1. Preparing detailed activities and procedures and specialized work teams for the implementation of the provisions of this Memorandum.
2. Preparing annual cooperation plans for the various activities stipulated in this Memorandum.
3. Determining the appropriate mechanisms and means approved by both parties for the implementation of the annual cooperation plan.
4. Monitoring and evaluating the level of achievement of the annual cooperation plan, addressing difficulties hindering its implementation, and preparing an annual report thereon to be submitted to both parties.
5. Evaluating and planning for future joint projects in accordance with this Memorandum.
6. Interpreting the provisions of this Memorandum and settling any difficulties that may arise during its implementation.
7. Proposing the review or amendment of all or some of the provisions of this Memorandum. The committee shall meet alternately in each of the two countries, whenever necessary, and the timing and venue of the meeting shall be determined by written agreement between the two parties. The meeting may be held using modern visual communication methods if necessary.

# Article Ten
## Financial Expenses
Each of the two Parties shall independently bear its own financial expenses arising from the implementation of any of the provisions of this Memorandum, in accordance with its applicable regulations, unless the Parties agree otherwise in writing.

# Article Eleven
## Intellectual Property
1. Without prejudice to any subsequent agreements between the Parties, none of the provisions of this Memorandum shall affect the ownership rights of either Party or its intellectual property rights, or any modifications, improvements, or derivations made to these rights by either Party prior to the signing of this Memorandum. Furthermore, the use of the name, logo, or official symbol of either Party on any publications, documents, or papers is prohibited without prior written consent from the Party holding the right.
2. For the purposes of this Memorandum, "Intellectual Property" rights include any or all rights related to copyright, distribution, and design rights, and all rights associated with or similar in nature to those mentioned above.

# Article Twelve
## International Obligations
The provisions of this Memorandum shall not prejudice the laws in force in either country or the rights or obligations of either country arising from international treaties and agreements to which it is a party.
The Parties shall consult and coordinate their positions whenever possible regarding issues and topics presented for research or discussion during attendance at meetings, conferences, or gatherings in international and regional forums, as well as during participation in activities related to work in this field. Opinions, advice, and proposals shall also be exchanged regarding ideas or solutions presented during these events.

# Article Thirteen
## Dispute Settlement
Any dispute that may arise concerning the implementation or interpretation of the provisions of this Memorandum shall be settled through consultations and negotiations between the Parties, via diplomatic channels.

# Article Fourteen
## Amendment
The provisions of this Memorandum or any of its texts may be amended by written agreement of the Parties. Such amendment shall be considered an integral part of this Memorandum and shall enter into force in accordance with the same procedures stipulated in Article Fifteen of this Memorandum.

# Article Fifteen
## Entry into Force, Duration, and Termination
This Memorandum shall enter into force on the date either Party receives a written notification from the other Party, via diplomatic channels, confirming the completion of the necessary internal legal procedures for this Memorandum to enter into force in both countries. This Memorandum shall remain valid for a period of (5) five years and shall be automatically renewed for one or more similar periods, unless one Party notifies the other Party in writing, via diplomatic channels, of its desire to terminate it, at least (6) six months prior to its termination date.
The termination of this Memorandum shall not affect ongoing activities under it, until their completion, unless the Parties agree otherwise in writing.
In witness whereof, the undersigned Plenipotentiaries, duly authorized by their respective Governments, have signed this Memorandum.
This Memorandum was drawn up and signed in the city of Doha <orig>الدوحة</orig>, on 4 Sha'ban 1446 Hijri, corresponding to 3 February 2025 AD, in two original copies in the Arabic language, each having equal and full legal validity.

# Decree No. 106 of 2025
## Approving an Air Services Agreement
## Between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>الكويت</orig> and the Government of Mongolia

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qa'dah 1445 AH, corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And Decree-Law No. 108 of 1976 concerning the exemption of Arab and foreign airlines from taxes, amended by Decree-Law No. 53 of 1979,
- And Decree No. 101 of 1996 approving the Protocol on the Quinquelingual Official Text of the Convention on International Civil Aviation (Chicago 1944),
- And Decree No. 104 of 2000 approving the Protocol on the Sexilingual Official Text of the Convention on International Civil Aviation (Chicago 1944),
- And based on the submission of the Minister of Foreign Affairs,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers,

We have decreed the following:

### Article One
Approval of the Air Services Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>الكويت</orig> and the Government of Mongolia, signed in the State of Kuwait <orig>الكويت</orig> on 19 January 2025, and its annexed Route Schedule, the texts of which are attached to this Decree.

Article 2
Application of the Convention
The provisions of this Agreement shall be subject to the provisions of the Chicago Convention <orig>معاهدة شيكاغو</orig> insofar as those provisions are applicable to international air transport services.

Article 3
Grant of Rights and Privileges
(1) Each Contracting Party grants to the other Contracting Party the rights specified in this Agreement for the purpose of operating international air services on the routes specified in the Route Schedule.
(2) Subject to the provisions of this Agreement, the designated air transport enterprise(s) of each Contracting Party shall enjoy the following rights:
a. The right to fly across the territory of the other Contracting Party without landing;
b. The right to make stops in the territory of the other Contracting Party for non-commercial purposes;
c. The right to make stops at points on the routes specified in the Route Schedule annexed to this Agreement for the purpose of taking on and putting down international air traffic of passengers, cargo, and mail; and
d. Other rights specified in this Agreement.
(3) Air transport enterprises of both Contracting Parties, other than those designated under Article (4) (Designation and Authorization) of this Agreement, shall be entitled to enjoy the rights specified in paragraphs (2)(a) and (2)(b) of this Article.
(4) Nothing in this Article shall be deemed to confer on a designated air transport enterprise(s) of one Contracting Party the privilege of taking on board, in the territory of the other Contracting Party, passengers, cargo, and mail for remuneration destined for another point in the territory of that other Contracting Party.

Article 4
Designation and Authorization
(1) Each Contracting Party shall have the right to designate in writing to the other Contracting Party one or more air transport enterprises for the purpose of operating the agreed services on the specified routes in accordance with this Agreement, and to withdraw or replace such designation.
(2) Upon receipt of such designation, and upon application by the designated air transport enterprise in the manner and procedure followed for operating authorization and technical license, each
have agreed as follows:

Article 1
Definitions
For the purpose of this Agreement, unless the context otherwise requires:
a) "Aeronautical Authorities" means, in the case of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>, the Directorate General of Civil Aviation <orig>الإدارة العامة للطيران المدني</orig>, and in the case of Mongolia, the Ministry of Roads and Transport <orig>وزارة الطرق والنقل</orig>, or in both cases, any other person or body entrusted with performing the functions currently exercised by these authorities.
b) "Agreed Services" means the scheduled air services on the routes specified in the Annex to this Agreement for the carriage of passengers, cargo, and mail in accordance with the agreed capacity provisions.
c) "Agreement" means this Agreement and its Annex, and any amendments thereto.
d) The terms "air service," "international air service," "stop for non-commercial purposes," and "air transport enterprise" for the purposes of this Agreement, shall all be interpreted with the meanings assigned to them in Article (96) of the Convention.
e) "Air Transport" means the public carriage by aircraft of passengers, cargo, and mail, separately or in combination, for remuneration or hire.
f) "Convention" means the Convention on International Civil Aviation <orig>معاهدة الطيران المدني الدولي</orig> opened for signature at Chicago on the seventh day of December 1944, including any Annex adopted pursuant to Article (90) of that Convention and any amendment to the Annexes or the Convention pursuant to Articles (90) and (94), insofar as such Annexes and amendments have been adopted by both Contracting Parties.
g) "Designated Air Transport Enterprise" means any air transport enterprise which one Contracting Party has designated in writing to the other Contracting Party in accordance with Article (4) of this Agreement as the air transport enterprise entitled to operate the agreed services on the specified routes in accordance with Article (3) of this Agreement.
h) "Route Schedule" means the Route Schedule annexed to this Agreement, or as it may be amended in accordance with the provisions of Article (17) of this Agreement.
i) "Tariff" means the prices to be paid for the carriage of passengers, baggage, and cargo and the conditions applicable to these prices, including the prices

c. the Contracting Party designating the air transport enterprise is applying the provisions specified in Article (15) and Article (16) of this Agreement; and

(3) Upon receipt of the operating authorization referred to in paragraph (2) of this Article, the designated air transport enterprise may at any time begin to operate the agreed services for which it has been designated, provided that the air transport enterprise applies the applicable provisions of this Agreement.

Article 5
Revocation, Restriction, and Imposition of Conditions
(1) The aeronautical authorities of each Contracting Party shall have the right to withhold the authorizations referred to in Article (4) of this Agreement from an air transport enterprise designated by the other Contracting Party, or to revoke, suspend, or impose conditions on such authorizations, temporarily or permanently, in case:
a. the designated air transport enterprise fails to maintain its principal place of business in the territory of the Contracting Party that designated it; or
b. the Contracting Party designating that enterprise fails to maintain effective regulatory control over that enterprise, or if the enterprise does not possess a valid Air Operator Certificate (AOC) issued by that Contracting Party; or
c. the Contracting Party designating the air transport enterprise fails to apply the provisions contained in Article (15) and Article (16) of this Agreement; or
d. the designated air transport enterprise fails to meet the conditions imposed under the laws and regulations ordinarily applied to the operation of international air transport services by the Contracting Party receiving the designation.
(2) Unless immediate action is essential to prevent non-compliance with the aforementioned laws and regulations, or unless action is required in accordance with the provisions of Articles (15) or (16) relating to safety or security, the rights contained in paragraph (1) of this Article shall not be exercised except after consultations between the civil aviation authorities in accordance with Article (17) of this Agreement.

Article 6
User Charges
(1) Neither Contracting Party shall impose, or permit to be imposed, user charges on the designated air transport enterprises of the other Contracting Party higher than those imposed on its own air transport enterprises operating similar international services.
(2) Each Contracting Party shall encourage consultations on user charges between the competent authority imposing user charges, or the airport service provider or air navigation service provider, and the air transport enterprises using those services and facilities provided by such authorities or service providers, wherever practicable, through organizations representing air transport enterprises. A reasonable advance notice shall be given for any proposals to change user charges to users of those services to enable them to express their views before the amendments are made. Also, each Contracting Party shall encourage the authorized charging authorities or service providers to exchange information regarding user charges.

Article 7
Exemption from Customs Duties and Other Charges
(1) Aircraft operating in international services of air transport enterprises designated by one Contracting Party, as well as their usual equipment, spare parts, quantities of fuel and lubricating oils, and aircraft stores (including food, beverages, and cigarettes) on board, shall be exempt from all customs duties, inspection fees, and any other levies or taxes upon arrival in the territory of the other Contracting Party, provided that such equipment and stores remain on board the aircraft until the time of its departure.
(2) Fuel, lubricating oils, spare parts, usual equipment, and aircraft stores introduced into the territory of each Contracting Party by or on behalf of the designated air transport enterprise(s) of the other Contracting Party, or supplied to aircraft operated by such enterprise(s) for the purpose of use in operating international air services, shall be exempt from all national duties and levies, including customs duties and inspection fees imposed in the territory of the other Contracting Party, even if these supplies are to be used on a part of the flights over the territory of the Contracting Party

### Article 14
**Determination of Tariffs**
(1) Both Contracting Parties shall permit the designated air carrier to establish tariffs for air services on a commercial market basis, including operating costs, service characteristics, user interests, reasonable profit, and any other market considerations.
(2) Both Contracting Parties may require notification or registration of tariffs imposed for flights to and from their territories with their respective aeronautical authorities by the designated air carriers of the other Contracting Party. The filing of such notification or registration may be required before the commencement of the offering of the tariff by the designated air carriers of both Contracting Parties.
(3) Without prejudice to the applicable and prevailing competition and consumer protection laws of each of the Contracting Parties, neither Contracting Party shall act unilaterally to prevent the initiation or continuation of a proposed or imposed tariff by a designated air carrier of the other Contracting Party related to the air services stipulated in this Agreement. Intervention, as described in paragraph (4) below, shall be limited to:
a. Preventing any unreasonable discriminatory prices or practices.
b. Protecting consumers from unreasonably high or restrictive prices due to the abuse of a dominant position or concerted practices among air carriers.
c. Protecting air carriers from artificially low prices.
(4) Without prejudice to the provisions of paragraph (3) of this Article, the aeronautical authorities of both Contracting Parties may reject a tariff submitted by the air carriers of the other Contracting Party if the aeronautical authorities discover that the tariff proposed by the air carriers falls within the scope of paragraph (3) of this Article. In this case, the concerned aeronautical authority shall:
a. Send a notice of dissatisfaction to the aeronautical authorities of the other Contracting Party and to the concerned air carrier at the earliest possible opportunity, and within a period not
(5) The primary objective for the provision of agreed services by the designated air carrier in accordance with this Agreement shall remain the availability of reasonable capacity that meets the air transport needs between the two countries, where the national air carrier and the country of final destination of transport operate. The exercise of the right to pick up or set down international air traffic at a point in the territory of the other Contracting Party coming from or destined for third countries at a point or points on the specified routes outlined in this Agreement shall be in accordance with the general principles for the orderly development of air transport traffic undertaken by both Parties and shall be subject to the general principle that capacity shall be proportionate to:
a. The needs of air traffic between the country of origin and the countries of ultimate destination of the air traffic;
b. The needs of transit operations carried out by the air carrier; and
c. The needs of air traffic in the region through which the air route passes, taking into account domestic and regional routes.
(6) Consultations shall be arranged between the Parties whenever either Party requests a review of the capacity offered under this Agreement to ensure the application of the principles contained in this Agreement for the operation of air routes.
(7) Each Contracting Party shall permit the designated air carrier to determine the capacity and number of flights for international air traffic it provides in accordance with commercial market needs. In accordance with this right, neither Contracting Party shall unilaterally restrict the operations of the air carriers of the other Party except in accordance with the terms of this Agreement or as may be required for customs, or for technical, operational, or environmental reasons, in accordance with the conditions mentioned in Article (15) of the Treaty.

### Article 12
**Approval of Operating Schedules and Timings**
(1) Designated air carriers shall submit to the competent aeronautical authorities of both Contracting Parties at least sixty (60) days prior to the commencement of the agreed services on the specified routes in accordance with Article (3) of this Agreement, specifying the nature of the service, the types of aircraft used, the flight schedule, and any subsequent modifications.
(2) The aeronautical authorities receiving these operating schedules shall approve them or propose any modifications thereto. In all cases, designated air carriers shall not commence their services before the schedules are approved by the concerned aeronautical authorities, and this principle shall apply to subsequent modifications.

## Article 15
### Aviation Safety
1) Each Contracting Party may at any time request consultations concerning the safety standards applied by the other Contracting Party in any area relating to aircraft crew, aircraft, or their operation. Such consultations shall begin within thirty (30) days from the date of that request.
2) If, after such consultations, one Contracting Party finds that the other Contracting Party does not effectively maintain and administer safety standards in any of those areas that are at least equivalent to the minimum standards established pursuant to the Convention, the first Contracting Party shall notify the other Contracting Party of such finding and the necessary steps to apply those minimum standards, and the other Contracting Party shall take appropriate corrective action. If the other Contracting Party fails to take such action within fifteen (15) days or any longer period as may be agreed upon, this shall constitute a basis for the application of Article (5) of this Agreement.
3) Notwithstanding the obligations mentioned in Article (16) and Article (33) of the Convention, it has been agreed that when an aircraft of an air transport enterprise or enterprises belonging to one Contracting Party operates air services to or from the territory of the other Contracting Party, while present within the territory of the other Contracting Party, the authorized representatives of that Contracting Party may subject the aircraft to an internal and external inspection to verify
of this person or designated air transport enterprise(s) includes the rights and conditions referred to in paragraph (8) of this Article concerning an aircraft operating the agreed services on the specified routes, and these rights or conditions were registered with the International Civil Aviation Organization <orig>منظمة الطيران المدني الدولي</orig>, but they allow for a deviation from the standards established under the Convention, then the aeronautical authorities of the other Contracting Party may request consultations with the aeronautical authorities of the first Contracting Party in accordance with the provisions of Article (17) of this Agreement with the aim of reaching a satisfactory agreement, and this shall constitute a basis for the application of the provisions of Article (5) of this Agreement.

# Article 16
## Aviation Security

Special provisions concerning aviation security. Both Contracting Parties shall notify the other Contracting Party of any differences between their national standards and practices relating to aviation security and the aviation security standards contained in the Convention. Either Contracting Party may request immediate consultations with the other Contracting Party concerning any such differences.

1.  The Contracting Parties affirm that their obligation, in conformity with their rights and obligations under international law, to protect the security of civil aviation from acts of unlawful interference, forms an integral part of this Agreement. Without limiting the generality of their rights and obligations under international law, the Contracting Parties shall act in particular in conformity with the provisions of the Convention on Offences and Certain Other Acts Committed on Board Aircraft, signed at Tokyo on 14 September 1963, the Convention for the Suppression of Unlawful Seizure of Aircraft, signed at The Hague on 16 December 1970, the Convention for the Suppression of Unlawful Acts against the Safety of Civil Aviation, signed at Montreal on 23 September 1971, and its Supplementary Protocol for the Suppression of Unlawful Acts of Violence at Airports Serving International Civil Aviation, signed at Montreal on 24 February 1988, the Convention on the Marking of Plastic Explosives for the Purpose of Detection, signed at Montreal on 1 March 1991, and any other international agreements relating to aviation security to which both Contracting Parties become parties.
2.  The Contracting Parties shall, upon request, provide all necessary assistance to each other to prevent acts of unlawful seizure of civil aircraft and other unlawful acts committed against the safety of such aircraft, their passengers and crew, airports and air navigation facilities, and any other threat to civil aviation security.
3.  The Contracting Parties shall, in their mutual relations, act in conformity with the aviation security standards, insofar as they are applied by the Contracting Parties, and recommended practices of the International Civil Aviation Organization <orig>منظمة الطيران المدني الدولي</orig> (ICAO) and its security annexes to the Convention. They shall require operators of aircraft registered in their territory, and operators who have their principal place of business or permanent residence in their territory, as well as operators of airports in their territory, to comply with
4.  Each Contracting Party shall ensure that effective measures are taken within its territory to protect aircraft and to inspect passengers and their baggage, and to conduct appropriate verification of crew, cargo (including hold baggage), and aircraft stores prior to and during boarding or loading. Such measures shall be adjusted as necessary to meet any increased threat. Each Contracting Party agrees that its designated airline(s) may be required to observe the aviation security provisions referred to in paragraph (3) and required by the other Contracting Party for entry into, departure from, or while within the territory of the other Contracting Party. A Contracting Party shall act favorably upon any request from the other Contracting Party for special reasonable security measures to meet a particular threat.
5.  When an incident or threat of an incident of unlawful seizure of civil aircraft or other unlawful acts directed against the safety of such aircraft, their passengers, crew, airports or air navigation facilities occurs, the Contracting Parties shall assist each other by facilitating communications and other appropriate measures aimed at terminating such incident or threat as quickly as possible, to minimize the likelihood of endangering lives.
6.  Each Contracting Party shall take such measures as it may find practicable to ensure the detention of an aircraft that has been subjected to an act of unlawful seizure or other acts of unlawful interference in its territory, unless its departure is required to protect human life. Whenever practicable, such measures shall be taken on the basis of mutual consultations.
7.  When a Contracting Party has reasonable grounds to believe that the other Contracting Party has deviated from the provisions of this Article, the first Party shall have the right to request immediate consultations. Such consultations shall commence within fifteen (15) days of receipt of such a request from either Contracting Party. Failure to reach a satisfactory agreement within fifteen (15) days or any period agreed upon from the commencement of consultations shall constitute grounds for withholding, revoking, suspending, or imposing conditions on the authorization of the airline(s) designated by the other Party. When an emergency so justifies or to prevent further non-compliance with the provisions of this Article, the first Party shall have the right to take interim measures in this regard at any time. Any action taken in accordance with this paragraph shall be discontinued when the other Contracting Party complies with the security provisions of this Article.

### Article 17
Consultations and Amendments
1) The aeronautical authorities of the two Contracting Parties shall consult with each other to achieve closer cooperation and agreement on all matters relating to the application of this Agreement.
2) Either Contracting Party may at any time request consultations with the other Contracting Party for the purpose of amending this Agreement or the Route Schedule, provided that such consultations shall commence within thirty (30) days from the date of receipt of such request. Any amendments to this Agreement agreed upon as a result of these consultations shall be approved by each Contracting Party in accordance with its constitutional procedures and shall enter into force on the date of the exchange of diplomatic notes indicating such approval.
3) If the amendments relate only to the Route Schedule, consultations shall be held between the aeronautical authorities of the two Contracting Parties. When these authorities agree on a new or amended Route Schedule, the agreed amendments shall enter into force as soon as they are confirmed on the date agreed upon by the civil aviation authorities.

### Article 18
Settlement of Disputes
1) If any dispute arises between the two Contracting Parties concerning the interpretation or application of this Agreement, the two Contracting Parties shall first endeavor to settle it through negotiations between them.
2) If the two Contracting Parties fail to reach a settlement of the dispute through negotiations within sixty (60) days, they shall refer the matter of the dispute to a person or entity, or, at the request of one of the Contracting Parties, to an arbitration body for resolution. The arbitration body shall be constituted as follows:
a. Each Contracting Party shall nominate an arbitrator. If one of the Contracting Parties fails to nominate its arbitrator within sixty (60) days, the arbitrator shall be nominated by the President of the Council of the International Civil Aviation Organization <orig>منظمة الطيران المدني الدولي</orig> upon the request of the other Contracting Party.
b. The third arbitrator shall be a national of a third state, shall preside over the arbitration body, and shall be appointed as follows:
1. By agreement between the two Contracting Parties, or
2. If the two parties do not agree on his appointment within (60) days, he shall be appointed by the President of the Council of the International Civil Aviation Organization <orig>منظمة الطيران المدني الدولي</orig> upon the request of either Contracting Party. In the event that the President of the Council of the International Civil Aviation Organization <orig>منظمة الطيران المدني الدولي</orig> is of the same nationality as one of the Contracting Parties, the highest-ranking Vice-President who meets the eligibility requirements shall appoint the third arbitrator.
3) The arbitration body shall take its decisions by a majority vote. These decisions shall be binding on both Contracting Parties. Each Contracting Party shall bear the expenses of its own member as well as the costs of its representation in the arbitration sessions. The expenses of the President of the arbitration body and any other costs shall be borne equally by both Contracting Parties. In all other respects, the arbitration body shall determine its own procedures.
4) The arbitration body shall endeavor to render a written award within (60) days after the conclusion of the hearings, or, if no hearings are held, within (60) days of the submission of responses.
5) The decision of the arbitration body shall be final and binding on both parties to the dispute.
6) In the event that either Contracting Party fails to comply with the decision issued in accordance with paragraph (5) of this Article, the other Contracting Party shall have the right to restrict, suspend, or revoke any of the rights or privileges granted under this Agreement.

### Article 19
Termination of the Agreement
Either Contracting Party shall have the right to notify the other Party in writing through diplomatic channels at any time of its decision to terminate this Agreement. This shall coincide with sending a copy of this notification to the Secretary General of the International Civil Aviation Organization <orig>منظمة الطيران المدني الدولي</orig>. If such notification is made, this Agreement shall terminate twelve (12) months after the date of receipt of this notification by the other Contracting Party, unless it is withdrawn by agreement between the two Contracting Parties before the expiry of this period. In the event that the other Contracting Party does not acknowledge receipt of the notification, it shall be deemed to have been notified fourteen (14) days after the date of receipt by the Secretary General of the International Civil Aviation Organization <orig>منظمة الطيران المدني الدولي</orig> of his copy of the notification.

### Article 20
Conformity with Multilateral Treaties
In the event that a multilateral treaty on air transport enters into force concerning both Contracting Parties, this Agreement shall be amended to conform with the provisions of the multilateral treaty. Any consultations aimed at determining the extent to which this Agreement is terminated, suspended, amended, or supplemented in accordance with the provisions of the multilateral treaty shall be in accordance with paragraph (2) of Article (17) of this Agreement.

### Article 21
Registration
This Agreement and any amendment thereto shall be registered with the International Civil Aviation Organization <orig>منظمة الطيران المدني الدولي</orig>.

The Government of the State of Kuwait and the

## ARTICLE 1
### DEFINITIONS
For the purpose of this Agreement, unless the
text otherwise requires:
a) "Aeronautical Authorities" means in the case
of the State of Kuwait, the Directorate General
of Civil Aviation, and in the case of Mongolia.
Ministry of Road and Transport or in both cases
any other person or agency authorised to
perform the functions exercised at present by
the said authorities;
b) "Agreed Services" means scheduled air
services on the routes specified in the Annex to
this Agreement for the transport of passengers,
cargo and mail in accordance with the agreed
capacity entitlements;
c) "Agreement" means this Agreement, its
Annex, and any amendments thereto;
d) "Air Service", "International Air Service",
"Stop for Non-Traffic Purposes" and "Airline"
shall for the purpose of this Agreement, have
the meaning laid down in Article (96) of the
Convention;
e) "Air Transportation" means the public
carriage by aircraft of passengers.
baggage. cargo and mail. separately or in
combination. for remuneration or hire;
f) "Convention" means the Convention on
International Civil Aviation opened for
signature at Chicago on the seventh day of
December 1944, and includes any annex
adopted under Article (90) of that Convention
and any amendment of the Annexes or
Convention under Articles (90) and (94) thereof
so far as these Annexes and amendments have
been adopted by both Contracting Parties;
g) "Designated Airline" means any airline that
one Contracting Party has designated in writing
to the other Contracting Party in accordance
with Article (4) of this Agreement as being an
airline which is to operate the agreed services on
the routes specified in accordance with Article
(3) of this Agreement;
h) "Route Schedule" means the Route Schedule
annexed to this Agreement or as amended in
accordance with the provisions of Article (17) of
this Agreement;
i) "Tariff" means the prices to be paid for the
carriage of passengers, baggage and cargo and
the conditions under which those prices apply,
including prices and conditions for agency and
other auxiliary services, but excluding
remuneration and conditions for the carriage of
mail;
j) "Territory" in relation to a State, has the
meaning assigned to it in Article (2) of the
Convention;
k) "User Charge" means a charge made to
airlines for the provision of airport, air
navigation or aviation security property , or
facilities.

## ARTICLE 2
### APPLICABILITY OF THE CONVENTION
The provisions of this Agreement shall be
subject to the provisions of the Chicago
Convention insofar as those provisions areapplicable to international air services.

## ARTICLE 3
### GRANTING OF RIGHTS AND PRIVILEGES
1) Each Contracting Party grants to the other
Contracting Party the rights specified in this
Agreement for the purpose of operating
international air services on the routes specified
in the Route Schedule.
2) Subject to the provisions of this Agreement,
the airline or airlines designated by each
Contracting Party shall enjoy the following
rights:
a) The right to fly without landing across the
territory of the other Contracting Party:
b) The right to make stops in the territory of the
other Contracting Party for non-traffic
purposes:
c) The right to make stops at the point(s) on the
route(s) specified in the Route Schedule of this
Agreement for the purpose of taking on board
and discharging international traffic in
passengers. cargo and mail: and
d) The rights otherwise specified in this
Agreement.
3) The airlines of each Contracting Party, other
than those designated under Article (4) of this
Agreement. shall also enjoy the rights specified
in paragraphs 2(a) and 2(b) of this Article.
4) Nothing in this Article shall be deemed to
confer on the designated airline(s) of one
Contracting Party the privilege of taking on
board, in the territory of the other Contracting
Party. passengers. cargo and mail for
remuneration and destined for another point in
the territory of the other Contracting Party.

## ARTICLE 4
### DESIGNATION AND AUTHORIZATION
1) Each Contracting Party shall have the right to
designate in writing to the other Contracting
Party one or more airlines to operate the agreed
services on the specified routes in accordance
with this Agreement, and to withdraw or alter
such designation.
2) On receipt of such a designation, and of
application from the designated airline, in the
form and manner prescribed for operating
authorization, and technical permission, each
Contracting Party shall grant the appropriate
operating authorization with minimum
procedural delay to exercise the rights specified
in Article (3) of this agreement, provided that:
a. the airline has its principal place of business
and permanent residence in the territory of the
Contracting Party designating that airline; and
b. the Contracting Party designating the airline
maintains effective regulatory control of the
airline. and that airline holds a valid Air
Operator's Certificate (AOC) issued by that
Contracting Party; and
c. the Contracting Party designating the airline
is in compliance with the provisions set forth in
Article (15) and Article (16) of this Agreement;
and
d. the designated airline is qualified to meet
other conditions prescribed under the laws and
regulations normally applied to the operation of
international air transport services by the
Contracting Party receiving the designation.
3) On receipt of the operating authorization of
paragraph (2) of this Article. A designated
airline may at any time begin to operate the
agreed services for which it is so designated.
provided that the airline complies with the
applicable provisions of this Agreement.

## ARTICLE 5
### REVOCATION, LIMITATION AND
### IMPOSITION OF CONDITIONS
1) The aeronautical authorities of each
Contracting Party shall have the right to
withhold the authorizations referred to in
Article (4) of this Agreement with respect to an
airline designated by the other Contracting
Party, and to revoke, suspend or impose
conditions on such authorizations, temporarily
or permanently when:
a. the airline does not have its principle place of
business or its permanent residence in the
territory of the Contracting Party designating
that airline; or
b. the Contracting Party designating the airline
fails to maintain effective regulatory control of
the airline. and that airline fails to holds a valid

## ARTICLE 6
## USER CHARGES

1) Neither Contracting Party shall impose or
permit to be imposed on the designated airlines
of the other Contracting Party user charges
higher than those imposed on its own airlines
operating similar international services.
2) Each Contracting Party shall encourage
consultations on user charges between its
competent charging authority or airport or air
navigation service provider and airlines using
the service and facilities provided by those
charging authorities or service providers, where
practicable through those airlines'
representative organizations. Reasonable notice
of any proposals for changes in user charges
should be given to such users to enable them to
express their views before changes are made.
Each Contracting Party shall further encourage
its competent charging authority. or service
providers, and such users to exchange
appropriate information concerning user
charges.

## ARTICLE 7
## EXEMPTIONS FROM CUSTOM DUTIES
## AND OTHER CHARGES

1) Aircrafts operated on international air
services by the designated airline(s) of one
Contracting Party, as well as their regular
equipment, spare parts, supplies of fuels and
lubricants and aircraft stores (including food,
beverages and tobacco) on board such aircraft
shall be exempt from all customs duties,
inspection fees and other duties or taxes on
arriving in the territory of the other Contracting
Party, provided such equipment and supplies
remain on board the aircraft up to such time as
they are re-exported.
2) Supplies of fuels, lubricants, spare parts,
regular equipment and aircraft stores
introduced in the territory of each Contracting
Party or on behalf of the designated airline(s) of
the other Contracting Party or taken on board
the aircraft operated by such designated
airline(s) and intended solely for use in the
operation of international air services shall be
exempt from all national duties and charges,
including customs duties and inspection fees
imposed in the territory of the first Contracting
Party, even when those supplies are to be used
on the parts of the journey performed over the
territory of the Contracting Party in which they
are taken on board. The materials referred to
above may be required to be kept under

3) The regular airborne equipment, spare parts,
aircraft stores and supplies of fuels and
lubricants retained on board the aircraft of

that Contracting Party, who may require that
those materials be placed under their

4) Moveable properties of the designated

equipment, stationery, travel documents
including airline tickets, airway bills as well as
publicity material and give-away items,
introduced in the territory of the other

### ARTICLE 10
### ENTRY AND CLEARANCE REGULATIONS
1) The laws, rules and regulations in force at each Contracting Party relating to entry into or departure from its territory of passengers, crew, cargo and mail of aircraft (such as regulation relating to entry, clearance, immigration, passports, Customs and quarantine) shall be applicable to the passengers, crew, cargo and mail of the aircraft of an airline designated by the other Contracting Party while in the territory of the first Contracting Party.
2) The laws and regulations of a Contracting Party relating to the admission to, Stay in, or departure from its territory of aircraft engaged in international air navigation, or to the operation and navigation of such aircraft while within its territory, shall be applied to the aircraft of both Contracting Parties without distinction as to nationality.

### ARTICLE 11
### CAPACITY PROVISIONS
1) Each designated airline shall have a fair and equal opportunity to provide the agreed services specified in the Agreement.
2) Each Contracting Party agrees to take action to eliminate all forms of discrimination or unfair competitive practices adversely affecting the competitive position of a designated airline of the other Contracting Party.
3) The air transport facilities available to the
Contracting Party shall be exempt from all customs duties. Inspection fees and other duties or taxes.
5) In the event that the designated airline or airlines of one Contracting Party owing to an emergency situation enter into arrangement with another airline or airlines for the loan or use of any of the items specified in paragraphs (1), (2) and (3) of this Article, the relieves provided in this article shall be available to such airline.

### ARTICLE 8
### FINANCIAL PROVISIONS
Subject to the national laws and regulations of each Contracting Party, each Contracting Party undertakes to grant the designated airline or airlines of the other Contracting Party the right of free transfer, at the applicable rate of exchange, of the excess of receipts over expenditure (including any interest earned on deposit awaiting remittance) achieved in its territory in connection with the carriage of passengers, baggage, mail shipments and cargo by the designated airline or airlines of the other Contracting Party. Whenever the payments system between the Contracting Parties is governed by a special agreement, that agreement shall apply.

### ARTICLE 9
### TECHNICAL AND COMMERCIAL REPRESENTATION
1) The designated airline or airlines of one Contracting Party shall have the right to maintain its own representation in the territory of the other Contracting Party.
2) The designated airline or airlines of one Contracting Party may, in accordance with the laws and regulations of the other Contracting Party relating to entry, residence and employment bring in and maintain in the territory of the other Contracting Party managerial sales, technical, operational and other specialist staff required for the provision of air services.
3) Subject to the exclusion in paragraph (4) of this Article, the designated airline or airlines of

## ARTICLE 12
TIMETABLE SUBMISSION AND SLOTS
1) The designated airlines shall submit to the
relevant authorities of the Contracting
Parties not later than sixty (60) days prior to the
initiation of the agreed services on the specified
routes in accordance with Article (3) of this
Agreement, the type of service. aircraft and the

2) The relevant authorities receiving such Time

suggest modifications thereto. In any case the
designated airlines shall not commence their

the relevant authorities concerned. This
provision shall likewise apply to later changes.

## ARTICLE 13
INFORMATION AND STATISTICS
The Aeronautical Authorities of either
Contracting Party shall furnish to the
Acronautical Authorities of the other
Contracting Party at their request such periodic
or other statistical data as as may be reasonably
required.

## ARTICLE 14
ESTABLISHMENT OF TARIFFS
1) Each Contracting Party shall allow tariffs for
air services to be established by each
designated airline based on commercial
considerations in the market place. including
the cost of operation, the characteristics of the
service, the interests of users, a reasonable profit
and other market considerations.
2) Each Contracting Party may require notification to
or filing with its aeronautical authorities of tariffs to
be charged to or from its territory by airlines of the
other Contracting Party. Such notification or filing
by the airlines of both Contracting Parties may be

services covered by this Agreement.
5) Services provided by a designated airline
under the Agreement shall retain as their
primary objective the provision of capacity
adequate to the traffic demands between the
countries of which such airline is a national and
the country of ultimate destination of the
traffic. The right to embark or disembark on
such services international traffic destined for
and coming from third countries at a point or
points on the routes specified in this Agreement
shall be exercised in accordance with the
general principles of orderly development of
international air transport to which both
Contracting Parties subscribe and shall be
subject to the general principle that capacity
should be related to:
a. The traffic requirements between the country
of origin and the countries of ultimate
destination of the traffic;
b. The requirements of through airline
operations; and
c. The traffic requirements of the area through
which the airline passes, after taking account of
local and regional services.
6) Consultations between the Contracting
Parties shall be arranged whenever a
Contracting Party requests that the capacity
provided under the Agreement be reviewed to
ensure the application of the principles in the
Agreement governing the conduct of the
services.
7) Each Contracting Party shall allow each
designated airline to determine the frequency
and capacity of the international air transport it

action within fifteen (15) days or such longer

application of Article (5) of this Agreement.

## ARTICLE 17
### CONSULTATIONS AND MODIFICATIONS
1) Consultations shall take place as needed between the Aeronautical Authorities of the Contracting Parties in order to achieve closer cooperation and agreement in all matters pertaining to the application of this Agreement.
2) Each Contracting Party may at any time request consultations with the other Contracting Party for the purpose of amending this Agreement or the Route Schedule. Such consultations shall begin within a period of thirty (30) days from the date of receipt of such request. Any amendment to this Agreement agreed to as a result of such consultations shall be approved by each Contracting Party in accordance with its constitutional procedures and shall enter into force on the date of exchange of diplomatic notes indicating such approval.
3) If the amendment relates to the Route Schedule, the consultations shall be between the Aeronautical Authorities of both Contracting Parties. When these authorities agree on a new or revised Route Schedule, the agreed amendments shall come into force on the date agreed by the Aeronautical Authorities.

## ARTICLE 18
### SETTLEMENT OF DISPUTES
1) If any dispute arises between the Contracting Parties relating to the interpretation or application of this Agreement, the Contracting Parties shall in the first place endeavor to settle it by negotiations between themselves.
2) If the Contracting Parties fail to reach within sixty (60) days a settlement by negotiations they shall refer the dispute for decision to a person or body or at the request of one of the Contracting Parties to an arbitration tribunal. The arbitration tribunal shall be composed as follows:
    a. Each Contracting Party shall nominate an arbitrator; if one Contracting Party fails to nominate its arbitrator within sixty (60) days, such arbitrator shall be nominated by the President of the Council of the International Civil Aviation Organization at the request of the other Contracting Party.
    b. The third arbitrator, who shall be a national of a third state and who shall preside over the arbitration tribunal, shall be nominated either:
        i. By agreement between the Contracting Parties; or
        ii. If within sixty (60) days the Contracting Parties do not so agree, by appointment of the President of the Council of the International Civil Aviation Organization by the request of either Contracting Party. If the President of the Council is of the same nationality as one of the Contracting Parties, the most senior Vice President who is not disqualified on that ground shall make the appointment.
3) The arbitral tribunal shall reach its decisions by a majority of votes. Such decisions shall be binding on both Contracting Parties. Each Contracting Party shall bear the cost of its own member as well as of its representation in the

### ARTICLE 21
## REGISTRATION
This Agreement and any amendment thereto shall be registered with the International Civil Aviation Organization.

## TITLES
Titles are inserted in this Agreement at the head of each Article for the purpose of reference and convenience and in no way to define, limit or describe the scope or intent of this Agreement.

## ENTRY INTO FORCE
This Agreement shall enter into force after the fulfillment of the internal legal requirements by each Contracting Party. which shall notify each other of the fulfillment of such requirements through exchange of the diplomatic notes. 5) The decision of the arbitral tribunal shall be final and binding upon the parties to the dispute.

### ARTICLE 19
## TERMINATION
Either Contracting Party may at any time notify the other Contracting Party in writing through diplomatic channels of its decision to terminate this Agreement. A copy of the notice shall be sent simultaneously to the Secretary General of the International Civil Aviation Organization. If such notice is given, this Agreement shall terminate twelve (12) months after the date of receipt by the other Contracting Party of the notice to terminate, unless by agreement between the Contracting Parties the notice under reference is withdrawn before the expiry of that period. If the other Contracting Party fails to acknowledge receipt, notice shall be deemed to have been received fourteen (14) days after the date of the receipt by the Secretary General of the International Civil Aviation Organization of his copy.

# Decree No. 109 of 2025
## Regarding the Withdrawal of Kuwaiti Citizenship
## From a Person
- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And Amiri Decree No. 15 of 1959 regarding the Kuwaiti Nationality Law,
- And based on the submission of the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Interior,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers,
We have decreed the following:
### Article One
Kuwaiti citizenship shall be withdrawn from / Jad'an Ali Harwi Al-Enezi <orig>جدعان علي حروي العنزي</orig>, and from anyone who may have acquired it derivatively through him.
### Article Two
The First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Interior shall implement this Decree, which shall be effective from the date of its issuance and published in the Official Gazette.

# Decree No. 108 of 2025
## Regarding the Revocation of Kuwaiti Citizenship
## From a Person
- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And Amiri Decree No. 15 of 1959 regarding the Kuwaiti Nationality Law,
- And based on the submission of the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Interior,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers,
We have decreed the following:
### Article One
Kuwaiti citizenship shall be revoked from / Othman Hammoud Abdullah Rashid Salem Al-Shammari <orig>عثمان حمود عبدالله راشد سالم الشمري</orig>.
### Article Two
The First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Interior shall implement this Decree, which shall be effective from the date of its issuance and published in the Official Gazette.

Amir of Kuwait
Mishal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah <orig>مشعل الأحمد الجابر الصباح</orig>

Prime Minister
Ahmed Abdullah Al-Ahmad Al-Sabah <orig>أحمد عبد الله الأحمد الصباح</orig>

First Deputy Prime Minister
and Minister of Interior
Fahad Yusuf Saud Al-Sabah <orig>فهد يوسف سعود الصباح</orig>

Issued at Seif Palace on 19 Dhu al-Hijjah 1446 AH
Corresponding to: 15 June 2025 AD

Kuwaiti citizenship shall be withdrawn from those mentioned below, and from anyone who may have acquired it through them by dependency.

Sheikh Meshal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah <orig>الشيخ مشعل الأحمد الجابر الصباح</orig>
General Court
Bankruptcy Department
(Decision)
On Thursday, 2025/6/12, at the headquarters of the Bankruptcy Department
With the membership of Mr. / Imran Mohammed Al-Kandari <orig>عمران محمد الكندري</orig>, Bankruptcy Judge
And in the presence of Mr. / Yousef Ahmed Al-Bakar <orig>يوسف أحمد البكر</orig>, Secretary
In Application No. 3 / 2024 Preventive Settlement
And registered under automated number 194230 2 4 4
Submitted by: Penta Furniture and Furnishings Company W.L.L. <orig>شركة بنتا للأثاث والمفروشات ذ.م.م</orig>
Against:
1- Kuwait Finance House <orig>بيت التمويل الكويتي</orig>
2- Ahli United Bank <orig>البنك الأهلي المتحد</orig> - currently Kuwait Finance House <orig>بيت التمويل الكويتي</orig>
3- Warba Bank <orig>بنك وربة</orig>
4- Al-Mulla Finance Company <orig>شركة الملا للتمويل</orig>
5- Industrial Bank <orig>البنك الصناعي</orig> and others
After reviewing the application and the attached documents.
Whereas the facts conclude that the applicant / Penta Furniture and Furnishings Company (W.L.L.) <orig>شركة بنتا للأثاث والمفروشات (ذ.م.م)</orig> submitted an application to the Bankruptcy Department in its capacity as (debtor) for a preventive settlement against 1- Kuwait Finance House <orig>بيت التمويل الكويتي</orig> 2- Ahli United Bank <orig>البنك الأهلي المتحد</orig> - currently Kuwait Finance House <orig>بيت التمويل الكويتي</orig> 3- Warba Bank <orig>بنك وربة</orig> 4- Al-Mulla Finance Company <orig>شركة الملا للتمويل</orig> 5- Industrial Bank <orig>البنك الصناعي</orig> and others.
Furthermore, the applicant company's operations are capable of continuing, based on a technical study by Crow Kuwait Consulting <orig>كرو كويت للاستشارات</orig>, registered with regulatory authorities, and that the applicant debtor has a plan to conduct business, has future financial flows, and that the creditors are holders of ordinary debts. The total bank debts amount to two million five hundred eighty-nine thousand and forty-one Kuwaiti Dinars <orig>دينار كويتي</orig>, supplier debts amount to one million eight hundred forty-three thousand and ten Kuwaiti Dinars <orig>دينار كويتي</orig>, and employee debts amount to one million four hundred thirty-four thousand three hundred sixteen Kuwaiti Dinars <orig>دينار كويتي</orig>.
There are also debts to other parties amounting to one million six hundred eighty thousand seven hundred Kuwaiti Dinars <orig>دينار كويتي</orig>, and the book value of assets is 650,357 Kuwaiti Dinars <orig>دينار كويتي</orig>. There are methods to extinguish accumulated losses, and there is a financial study with a preventive settlement plan. Evidence and documents demonstrating its ability to continue and extinguish its losses within a short period were submitted. Documents were submitted, the most important of which include (an extraordinary general assembly resolution, a letter classifying creditors and outstanding and submitted amounts, a copy of the inventory and assets list, and financial statements for banks, suppliers, and employees). Consequently, the company became unable to pay its debts due to that prohibition.
At the session on 2024/12/26, the applicant company's lawyer submitted a defense memorandum and a portfolio of documents demonstrating its ability to continue and pay creditors' debts in light of the preventive settlement plan submitted by it, especially since the applicant company had outlined in its application a summary of the proposed preventive settlement, and the agreements intended to be concluded with creditors regarding the settlement. It clarified its desire to be granted sufficient time to settle the debts outstanding against it, in order to preserve the company's entity, the value of its assets, and the interests of its shareholders, while affirming its ability to fulfill all those debts. The session began, and a decision was issued (to address the Bankruptcy Committee <orig>لجنة الإفلاس</orig> to examine the application and provide an opinion on it, clarify the possibility of preventive settlement, assess the debtor's financial situation and outstanding debts, indicate whether precautionary measures should be taken or not, and indicate whether the debtor is capable of managing his affairs and funds himself or not, and to provide us with a detailed report on this, working whenever possible to complete this according to the legal deadlines set for doing so in accordance with the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig>, and to indicate the need to appoint a supervisor to examine the proposed preventive settlement, the measures taken, and whether its proposal is implemented or not, and in the former case, to state the value of the financial amount due to the supervisor, whether monthly or annually).
And whereas the latest letter from the Bankruptcy Committee <orig>لجنة إفلاس</orig> dated 2025/6/12 was received
(1 - The proposed (amended) preventive settlement plan is acceptable in principle, as stated in item Third. 2 - Appointment of a supervisor, as stated in item Fifth).
And whereas the Bankruptcy Judge decided to present the papers for today's session to act on the request to initiate preventive settlement procedures according to the presented facts.

## Legal Basis
Whereas it is stipulated in the texts of Articles 1, 29, 33, 58/7 and its last paragraph, and 61 of the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig> issued by Law No. 71 of 2020 that, in applying the provisions of this Law, the following words and phrases shall have the meaning indicated opposite each of them: Suspension of Claims: Suspension of any lawsuit
